name: atacseq-regulatory-landscape
title: ATAC-seq Regulatory Landscape Discovery
description: Comprehensive regulatory element discovery using ATAC-seq. Maps enhancers, promoters, and TF binding patterns with motif analysis and footprinting to define cell-type regulatory architecture.
content:
ATAC-seq Regulatory Landscape Discovery

Comprehensive analysis to map the complete regulatory landscape of a cell type or condition. Goes beyond simple accessibility to annotate enhancers, identify active TFs, and discover regulatory logic.

What is a Regulatory Landscape?

The regulatory landscape is the complete map of regulatory elements (enhancers, promoters, silencers, insulators) and the transcription factors that bind them to control gene expression in a specific cell type or condition.

Why Map Regulatory Landscapes?

  • Cell Identity: Regulatory elements define cell type (muscle vs neuron)
  • Master Regulators: Identify TFs driving cell fate
  • Disease Mechanisms: GWAS variants often fall in regulatory elements
  • Drug Discovery: Target TFs controlling disease genes
  • Development: How regulatory landscapes change during differentiation
  • Evolution: Regulatory changes drive species differences

Regulatory Element Types

Promoters:

  • Core promoter: TSS ± 50bp
  • Proximal promoter: TSS ± 1kb
  • Open chromatin at TSS: Active gene
  • Multiple TSS: Alternative promoters

Enhancers:

  • Distal regulatory elements: 1kb-1Mb from gene
  • Cell-type specific: Define identity
  • Super-enhancers: Clusters of enhancers at key genes
  • Shadow enhancers: Redundant elements

Insulators:

  • CTCF binding sites: Block enhancer-promoter loops
  • TAD boundaries: 3D genome organization

Silencers:

  • Repressive elements: Suppress transcription

Enhancer Identification Strategy

ATAC-seq peaks far from TSS are likely enhancers:

  1. Distance from TSS: >1kb from any gene
  2. Nucleosome-free region (NFR): Fragment size <100bp
  3. Motif enrichment: TF motifs in peak
  4. Conservation: Evolutionarily conserved
  5. H3K4me1/H3K27ac: Integrate with ChIP-seq if available

Transcription Factor Footprinting

Concept: Bound TFs protect DNA from Tn5 cutting, leaving "footprints" (local depletion of ATAC signal) within accessible regions.

Analysis:

  • Look for dips in ATAC signal within peaks
  • Match footprint shape to known TF motifs
  • Infer which TFs are actively bound
  • NO ANTIBODIES NEEDED!

Footprinting Tools:

  • TOBIAS: Transcription factor Occupancy prediction By Investigation of ATAC-seq Signal
  • HINT-ATAC: Footprint detection
  • PIQ: Protein Interaction Quantitation

Super-Enhancer Discovery

Super-enhancers are clusters of enhancers driving cell identity genes:

  • Definition: Top ~5% of enhancers by ATAC signal
  • Features: Very high accessibility, multiple TF binding sites
  • Target genes: Master regulators, lineage-defining genes
  • Examples: MYC super-enhancer in cancer, OCT4/SOX2 in stem cells

Regulatory Logic Discovery

Motif Analysis:

  • Enriched motifs: Which TF families are active?
  • Co-occurring motifs: TFs that work together
  • Motif spacing: Distance constraints between TFs

Combinatorial TF Binding:

  • AND logic: Both TF-A and TF-B needed
  • OR logic: Either TF-A or TF-B sufficient
  • Ternary complexes: Three TFs cooperate

Pipeline Analysis

  1. Peak Calling: All accessible regions
  2. Peak Annotation: Classify as promoter/enhancer/intergenic
  3. Motif Discovery: De novo + known motif enrichment
  4. TF Footprinting: Predict active TFs
  5. Super-Enhancer Calling: ROSE algorithm
  6. Enhancer-Gene Linking: Correlate accessibility with expression
  7. Regulatory Network: Build TF→gene interactions
  8. Pathway Enrichment: What pathways are regulated?

Integration with Other Data

RNA-seq:

  • Correlate ATAC peaks with gene expression
  • Identify functional enhancers (high accessibility + high expression)
  • Validate TF targets

ChIP-seq:

  • Validate footprinted TFs with ChIP data
  • Add histone marks to classify enhancers (H3K4me1, H3K27ac)

Hi-C:

  • Link distal enhancers to target genes via 3D contacts
  • Validate enhancer-promoter loops

GWAS:

  • Overlap disease SNPs with regulatory elements
  • Mechanistic insights into non-coding variants

Scientific Questions

  • Cell Identity: What enhancers define this cell type?
  • Master Regulators: Which TFs control the regulatory program?
  • Differentiation: How does the regulatory landscape change?
  • Disease Enhancers: Oncogenic enhancers in cancer (e.g., MYC amplification)
  • GWAS Mechanisms: Do disease SNPs disrupt TF binding?
  • Evolution: Are regulatory elements conserved across species?

Applications

  • Cancer: Oncogenic super-enhancers (MYC, TAL1), targeted with BET inhibitors
  • Immunology: Immune cell identity enhancers, cytokine regulation
  • Stem Cells: Pluripotency regulatory network (OCT4, SOX2, NANOG)
  • Development: Stage-specific enhancers during organogenesis
  • Disease Modeling: Patient-specific regulatory variants
  • Drug Discovery: Target TFs in disease super-enhancers

Example: T Cell Activation

Question: What is the regulatory landscape of activated vs naive T cells?

ATAC-seq Reveals:

  • Naive T cells: TCF1, LEF1 enhancers (quiescence)
  • Activated T cells: NF-κB, AP-1, NFAT enhancers (activation)
  • Gained peaks: 5000+ new accessible regions upon activation
  • Lost peaks: Naive-specific enhancers close
  • Super-enhancers: IL2, IFNG loci in activated cells

Conclusion: Activation rewires regulatory landscape via NF-κB/AP-1/NFAT

Input Requirements

CSV samplesheet with columns:

  • sample: Sample name
  • fastq_1: Path to R1 FASTQ
  • fastq_2: Path to R2 FASTQ
  • replicate: Biological replicate number

Optionally provide RNA-seq data for enhancer-gene linking

Key Outputs

  • Annotated Peaks: Promoters, enhancers, intergenic regions
  • Motif Enrichment: Active TF families
  • TF Footprints: Predicted bound TFs at base-pair resolution
  • Super-Enhancers: Top enhancers driving cell identity
  • Regulatory Network: TF-gene interaction graph
  • Enhancer-Gene Links: Putative enhancer targets
  • Differential Accessibility: Condition-specific regulatory elements
  • Pathway Enrichment: Regulated biological processes

Perfect for: Enhancer discovery • TF activity • Cell identity • Super-enhancers • Regulatory networks • GWAS interpretation
